clinical_study.official_title: A Controlled Trial to Assess the Effect of a Health Promotion Intervention on Hygiene Behavior and Illness Absenteeism in Jerusalem Preschools

collaborator.agency: Israel National Institute for Health Policy and Health Services Research

brief_summary.textblock: The primary objective of this preschool intervention trial was to determine whether a hygiene program can promote handwashing and thereby reduce illness absenteeism.

detailed_description.textblock: Please see citations of published reports.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Each school day during study period

arm_group.description: Preschools randomized to this group received a multicomponent intervention to improve handwashing behavior of the children. Children within the preschool intervention group were individually randomized to a home intervention or a home control intervention program. The children in this arm received the home intervention component.
This group did not receive any special treatment during the study, but did receive the intervention at the close of the study

Preschools randomized to this group received a multicomponent intervention to improve handwashing behavior of the children. Children within the preschool intervention group were individually randomized to a home intervention or a home control intervention program. The children in this arm received the home control component.

intervention.description: This preschool-based intervention program used a multi-pronged approach that included elements aimed at preschool staff, children, and school nurses, as well as hygienic changes to the classroom environment.
The home component was intended to reinforce handwashing practices through education in the home. It consisted of a video, a magnet, and a card.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Preschool teachers of 3- and 4-year-old children in the state-run public system of the Jerusalem region, who were recommended by their supervisors as being likely to comply with the protocol.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Exposure to project during testing phase (N=1 preschool), preschool which included new Ethiopian immigrants who were unlikely to have phones or speak Hebrew (N=1 preschool)
- Project staff knew teachers personally and thought they would not comply with protocol (N=2 teachers).
